title: AFRL/RITQ Quantum Algorithms Research
description: Postdoctoral and senior researchers are invited to conduct quantum algorithms research at AFRL, focusing on amplitude amplification and quantum machine learning.
detailed_overview: This is a Research Associateship Program inviting postdoctoral and senior researchers to conduct quantum algorithms research at AFRL. The focus areas include amplitude amplification and quantum machine learning for near-term and future quantum devices. The typical duration for the associateship is 2-3 years, and the program includes relocation and health insurance benefits. Supplements may be provided based on experience.
eligibility: Open to U.S. citizens; requires PhD.
application_requirements: Must contact Research Adviser prior to applying

title: Grand Challenges Program (Quantum Research Collaboration)
funder: P33 and the National Quantum Algorithm Center (NQAC) (Funded by Illinois)
description: This program awards grants to postdoctoral researchers to accelerate the development of real-world quantum applications through mandatory three-way partnerships between academia, quantum companies, and non-quantum industry partners.
detailed_overview: The Grand Challenges program is a collaborative initiative spearheaded by P33 and the National Quantum Algorithm Center (NQAC) to bolster Chicago and Illinois's position as a quantum innovation hub. The program totals $250,000 and will award two $125,000 grants to postdoctoral researchers. The core objective is to translate theoretical quantum advancements into practical industry solutions by focusing on industry-relevant applications. Successful applicants are required to establish a three-way partnership involving an Illinois-based academic institution, a quantum company already connected to the Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park (IQMP), and a non-quantum industry partner from sectors like finance, pharmaceuticals, or energy.
eligibility: Postdoctoral researchers are eligible. Funding requires a mandated three-way partnership: 1) An Illinois-based academic institution, 2) A quantum hardware or software company *already* connected to the Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park (IQMP), and 3) A non-quantum industry partner (e.g., finance, pharmaceuticals, or energy).
application_requirements: Collaboration with an Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park (IQMP) connected quantum company

title: Quantum SuperSEED Grant Call
description: Funding for bold, high-impact interdisciplinary quantum research led by Penn State faculty to invoke transformative research at the intersection of quantum sciences, engineering, and computation.
detailed_overview: The newly formed Penn State Quantum Hub, housed under the Penn State Institute for Computational and Data Sciences (ICDS), aims to build a community and invest in bold, high-impact interdisciplinary quantum research through the Quantum SuperSEED Grant program. The funding opportunity is specifically designed to invoke transformative, interdisciplinary research at the intersection of quantum sciences, engineering and computation. Proposals are welcome in areas such as Quantum Computing and Algorithms, Quantum Machine Learning and AI, Quantum Sensing and Metrology, and Systems Engineering. Up to two research proposals will be selected, each receiving $200,000 for one year. Awarded funding can be used for supporting graduate students or postdoctoral scholars, minor research equipment and materials, computational resources, and travel for collaborations and dissemination.
eligibility: Penn State faculty in any discipline with an interest in applying quantum sciences methodologies to research are encouraged to submit a proposal. Proposals MUST be led by Penn State faculty members and include at least two faculty members from different departments or research units in order to be considered. Each individual may be listed on at most two proposal submissions. Of these, an individual may serve as Principal Investigator (PI) on only one proposal.
application_requirements: Include at least two faculty members from different departments/research units
PI listed on only one proposal
